STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
September 2, 2021
Kathleen Schultz
Wellspring Lutheran Services -E. Lansing
3681 Okemos Road #500
Okemos, MI 48864
RE: License #: CB330371021
Wellspring Lutheran Services -E. Lansing
3681 Okemos Road #500
Okemos, MI 48864
Dear Ms. Schultz:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
8/25/21. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be
noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the MISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved. For repeat violations,
please identify why the previous CAP was not effective and what changes
will be made to ensure ongoing compliance.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 660-8309
enclosure
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12503 Policy and procedures.
(3) An agency shall provide a youth in independent living with a
copy of the agency's policies and procedures required by this
rule.
One of three Independent Living files did not have documentation the youth was
provided with a copy of the agency’s policies and procedures.
R 400.12505 Supervision.
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum supervision:
(b) At monthly intervals, ensure that the youth is complying
with the terms of the contract required by R 400.125010,
continues to reside in a safe and acceptable environment, and
is managing expenditures.
Three of three Independent Living files did not have monthly budgets.
File one: Budgets were missing for December 2020, January, and April 2021.
File two: Budgets were missing for January, April, and July 2021.
File three: Budgets were missing for January, February, and July 2021.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and
the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed and
updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
Three of three Independent Living files did not have a contract reviewed and
updated every 90 days.
File one and two: Both files were missing contracts due in May 2021.
File three: An updated contract was not completed from February to June 2021.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/19/19 RENEWAL, CAP approved 10/11/19
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
4

3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional MDHHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
FOM 801 Medical Passport
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child’s
current and complete health information.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Legal parents if the child is a temporary court ward. Quarterly.
At reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider: At or prior to each placement.
Quarterly.
Three of three foster care files did not meet this requirement.
Files one and two: Medical passports were not updated quarterly from September
2020 to April 2021.
File three: Medical passport from 1/21/21 did not have a parental signature to
indicate it had been provided to the parent.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
10/29/20 INTERIM, CAP approved 11/16/20
9/19/19 RENEWAL, CAP approved 10/11/19
FOM 722-08E Foster care action summary requirements
The Foster Care/Juvenile Justice (FC/JJ) Action Summary,
DHHS-69 (RFF 69), is used whenever there is “action” on a
case.
The caseworker must complete the DHS-69, Foster
Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary and upload to
MiSACWIS within the timeframe required for the specified
action/change.
Prior to a planned placement change, or within three business
days of an emergency placement change…
5

Two of three open foster care cases did not meet this requirement:
File one: The youth moved on 4/15/21; the DHHS-69 was not completed until 6/3/21.
File two: The youth moved on 6/1/21; the DHHS-69 was not completed until 8/3/21.
Two of two closed foster care cases did not meet this requirement:
File one: A closing DHHS-69 was not on file.
File two: The case closed 1/4/21; a DHHS-69 was not completed until 1/26/21.
One of three open independent living cases did not meet this requirement. The
youth moved on 11/5/20; a DHHS-69 was not completed. The youth moved again on
1/27/21; a DHHS-69 was not completed until 4/6/21.
Two of two closed independent living cases did not meet this requirement:
File one: A closing DHHS-69 was not on file.
File two: The case closed on 11/2/2020; a DHHS-69 was not completed until
11/16/20.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
10/29/20 INTERIM, CAP approved 11/16/20
9/19/19 RENEWAL, CAP approved 10/11/19 (previously cited as 722-09C)
FOM 722-08C PATP signatures
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate, including
those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care worker, supervisor,
foster parent, caregiver, any youth age 14 and older and in the
case of placement agency foster care cases, the local DHS
office designee.
CI 17-099: When the treatment plan is completed, signatures for
all appropriate case members must be obtained. Signatures
from all appropriate case members, including youth ages 14 and
older for foster care and youth ages 11 and older for juvenile
justice, should be obtained before the corresponding court
hearing. All treatment plans with a report date of August 1,
2017, or later must have signatures from all appropriate case
members within 30 days of the report date.
6

Three of three foster care and one of three independent living files did not meet this
requirement.
File one: The 3/15/21 PATP was not signed by the parent until 6/9/21. The 6/12/21
PATP did not have a parent signature.
File two: The 2/25/21 PATP did not have a parent signature. The 11/27/20 PATP
was not signed by the foster parent until 6/18/21 and the parents on 4/26/21.
File three: The 12/5/20 PATP did not have parent signatures.
File four: (IL) The 12/22/20 PATP was not signed by the youth until 2/4/21.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
10/29/20 INTERIM, CAP approved 11/16/20
9/19/19 RENEWAL, CAP approved 10/11/19 (previously cited as ISEP 6.19)
FOM 722-06b Family Team Meetings
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables:
 Case Plan Reassessment (USP) Within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
 Semi Annual Transition Plan Meeting- Within 30 calendar
days after the youth’s 14th birthday and every six months
thereafter.
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for every FTM.
One of three foster care and three of three independent living files did not meet this
requirement:
File one: The FTM completed on 5/7/21 did not have an 1105 report completed.
Files two and three: (IL) Semi-annual transition plans were completed on 6/11/20
and 3/22/21, which are not within the required timeframe.
File four: (IL) The 3/2/21 USP did not have an FTM within 30 days prior to the report.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
10/29/20 INTERIM, CAP approved 11/16/20
9/19/19 RENEWAL, CAP approved 10/11/19
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility did not require technical assistance.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not request consultation.
7

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period. The CAP, approved 11/16/20, was
the result of the 10/29/20 interim review. In the 2020 interim review the agency was
cited for 11 licensing violations, including 6 repeat violations. During the 2021
renewal review, 7 licensing violations were found, including 5 repeat violations from
the 2019 and 2020 reviews. While there is still improvement to be made in some
areas, the agency appears to have effectively implemented their prior CAP and
shown improvement in many areas.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Annual Assessment dated 7/31/21 was reviewed. The CA
reported improvement in several areas over the past year including relative
placements, timeliness of medical exams, and service plans. However, the agency
continues to have difficulty meeting some timelines regarding supervision,
independent living, FTMs, and signatures. In addition, the agency reported some
inaccuracies in home visit data on the Monthly Management Report due to COVID
restrictions and how HVs were entered into the MISACWIS database. The agency
continues to utilize their previous CAP and adjust it as needed to improve in these
areas. The agency has continued policy/procedure reviews with staff, increased
oversight by supervisors, and use of protected time to assist workers in meeting
timeframes.
Interviews
Three staff were interviewed on-site. All staff reported facing challenges due to
COVID-19 over the past 17 months. However, all staff also reported feeling safe and
supported by their agency. Staff did not report any concerns or areas where they
felt the agency needed to focus on improvement.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
8

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules, MISEP requirements, and/or contract. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued
a renewal of their regular license.
August 26, 2021
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
August 26, 2021
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
9
